Award.AwardTitle: Computational problems in tensors and quantum information theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The first aim of this proposal is to develop theoretical and computational methods for common problems in tensors: small rank approximations, best rank approximations, uniqueness of best rank approximations, approximations of tensors preserving symmetries, rank of tensors, norm computations, finding the number of singular values tuples, computing singular value tuples, computing nonlinear eigenvalues. The second aim of this proposal is the use of theoretical and computational methods in tensors for central problems in Quantum Information Sciences: separability, the capacity of quantum channels and the computational complexity of these quantities.

High dimensional problems arise in many areas of applications such as mathematical biology, chemistry, physics, image processing, finance or engineering. The typical mathematical model uses tensors, i.e., multidimensional arrays, to represent the physical model and the computational methods for simulation and optimization can usually be based on operations with these tensors. For higher order tensors the theory and the development of numerical methods is much more complicated than for matrices, i.e. two dimensional arrays. The aim of this proposal to study, find and apply new techniques in tensors to advance the current machinery for applications in biology, engineering and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was dealing with two main areas in mathematics and mathematical physics.  The first main area was theoretical and numerical studies of mulitarrays, which are called tensors.  Tensors arise naturally when dealing with data with many parameters.  For example watching movie - two dimensional picture and voice.  Tensors arise also naturally in quantum mechanics when dealing with a quantum system with many particles.  For example two pairs of qubits.  Together with collaborators we found very important theoretical results on tensors.  We studied rank and approximation of tensors by low rank tensors.  We studied the nuclear and spectral norm of tensors and their computational complexity. We also designed and implemented a number of algorithms.  The most significant one was fast compression of tensors, which will enable to compress huge data appearing in applications.  It will aslo  will be useful in the engineering community for analyzing and storing big data with many parameters.  We also designed and implmented new algorithms to calculate the spectral and nuclear norms.  This will be useful in quantum information theory to estimate the entanglement and separability.

The second project was in matching theory in graphs.  This problem is related to the count of  the number of ways that n jobs can be filled out by n applicants.  These problems appear in stattistical mechanics. Together with collaborators we obtained a number of theoretical results that can be applied in statistical mechanics.
